intro: Galium pumilum proles hypnoides, commonly known as the creeping bedstraw, is a low-growing herbaceous plant native to parts of Asia and Africa. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its prostrate or ascending stems that often form dense mats. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in early spring. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to elliptic in shape, and covered with fine hairs. Galium pumilum proles hypnoides is often found in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
